title: An inside look at how the New York Times builds product | Alex Hardiman (CPO, the New York Times)
key_insights: Product managers at news organizations must blend art and science, valuing expert editorial judgment alongside traditional KPIs and data
Algorithms can be trained on editorial importance scores from journalists, not just engagement metrics, creating higher quality content curation
Crisis situations require 'wartime product management' - blowing up roadmaps and rallying teams around urgent, mission-critical work
Building a subscription bundle requires three pillars: best-in-class core product (news), adjacent products serving life needs, and connected product family
Product teams should include editors when working on journalism-related features to maintain editorial independence while improving user experience
Successful acquisitions require careful integration planning, especially when users have emotional connections to the acquired product
Focus and saying no to non-essential work is crucial for preventing team burnout during high-stress periods
Impact at mission-driven companies encompasses both business metrics and real-world outcomes like policy changes or public safety

guest_background.current_role: Chief Product Officer at The New York Times

topics_discussed: Career path from journalism to product management
Leading Facebook's news product post-2016 election
Product team structure with embedded editors
COVID-19 crisis response and product pivots
The Athletic acquisition for sports content
Remote work and hybrid office policies
Comparison with Substack and creator economy
Future vision for essential subscription bundle
memorable_quotes: Our impact and our business goals are in service of our mission, which is to seek the truth and help people understand the world, not the other way around.

When you're a product manager, you're involved in driving specific metrics like engagement or subscribers, but you're also trying to help stories find their real audience in ways that trigger just this whole different side of mission and purpose driven impact.

Product managers thrive in chaotic conditions - being able to take all of these crazy inputs, trying to create a very structured model to figure out what is true, where do we have conviction, and how do you get a team rallied around a shared context.
frameworks_mentioned: Solar system product strategy (news as the sun, other products as planets)
Art and science blend for editorial products

PMs interested in mission-driven product work

summary: Alex Hardiman shares insights on leading product at The New York Times, covering unique challenges of working with journalists, crisis product management during major news events, and building a subscription bundle strategy. The conversation offers valuable perspectives on mission-driven product development and the differences between traditional tech companies and media organizations.
